awd_titl_txt: CPS: Small: Cyber-Physical Communication for Cooperative Human-Robot Mobility
awd_abstract_narration:
Human-robot teams engaged in transportation and data collection will often share a common physical workspace. This project will investigate fundamental challenges in human-cyberphysical-systems (h-CPS) for cooperative aerial payload transport.  First, Unmanned Aerial Vehicles (UAVs) cooperatively lift and carry a payload through a cluttered environment under uncertain winds. The multi-UAV system (MUS) functions autonomously to allow human companions to focus attention on their environment while interacting with the MUS. We propose a novel interface where an operator pushes on the slung payload to guide the team and coordinates the mission through a networked tablet.  A novel cooperative control strategy safely guides the MUS while physics-based algorithms distinguish human inputs from environmental disturbances.  Flight tests will demonstrate and validate the h-CPS.  The PI and mentored postdoctoral researcher will involve students from under-represented groups and K-12 students in safe MUS flight demonstrations.

This project offers three research advances:  MUS scalability and collision avoidance guarantees through continuum deformation cooperative control, safe MUS compensation for vehicle anomalies, and cognitively-tractable user interfaces. Particularly novel to this work is the h-CPS interface in which an operator pushes on the payload to guide the MUS team.  We will apply linear momentum analysis to sense haptic cues and will validate our models in simulation and flight testing. Mission-level decision-making will be performed through system modeling as a Markov game in which game states are deﬁned from human, environment, and aggregate MUS state.  Our method abstracts MUS behaviors to reduce cognitive complexity and real-time network and computational overhead.

por.por_cntn:
This project extended the continuum deformation cooperative control theory to  enable a scalable multi-vehicle team to safely navigate through a cluttered environment with minimum communication overhead.  Continuum deformation theory was applied to assure safe tethered payload transport by a multiple quadcopter team.  The theory was further advanced to prove that user push forces directly guiding the slung payload will be accurately tracked with the cooperative quadcopter team. 

Theoretical and experimental advances were pursued in parallel throughout the project.  A custom quadcopter system was developed and instrumented to provide the first experimental validation of the continuum deformation cooperative control theory.  Teams of three to five quadcopters were flown indoors and in the University of Michigan's M-Air netted flight facility as shown in accompanying illustrations.  In the final project year, emphasis was placed on experimentation with an in situ user directly guiding the payload by pushing it.  User push inputs are characterized by tether force sensors providing haptic feedback to vehicle controllers.

This research was motivated by a vision that multiple small quadcopters can serve as a low-cost agile transport system for disaster relief supply delivery. A low-cost aerial system is critical when local roads are impassable.  A multiple small UAS (unmanned aircraft system) team cooperatively carrying a slung load is able to get near a user but lacks the local situational awareness on the ground to precisely place the load due to the natural disaster. The human has sufficient situational awareness and knows where to place the load but in general may be untrained and therefore needs an intuitive interface to guide the system. Our solution offers a provably-stable cooperative control scheme  that allows a user to push in the direction they want the payload to move and our system will respond appropriately.

Our team accomplished proposed theoretical and experimental objectives.  We completed and published the cooperative control theory necessary to realize scalable multi-quadcopter payload transport.  We developed and experimentally valided the first haptic guidance system for cooperative airborne payload transport.  Users indicated the pushing guidance was intuitive, and experimental results showed the system was able to reliably track user inputs. Future work will focus on eliminating dependency on motion capture sensor feedback and validating the system in more harsh environmental conditions, e.g., gusty winds.  The custom-built hardware and software have been open-sourced with a design and build guide available online.  Throughout this project we have given flight demonstrations and tours of our developed system to K-12 students interested in STEM.  We engaged local high school students and several undergraduate students in summer research experiences.

  • Four quadcopters are tethered to an instrumented payload for flight testing in the University of Michigan's M-Air netted facility. Quadcopters cooperatively lift and autonomously transport the payload along a prescribed payload trajectory. Tether forces augment motion capture and inertial data.
